body: Basketball Celtics vs. Detroit Pistons, at Boston. (Television -ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Inglewood, Calif. (Television - ESPN, 10:30 P.M.) title: SPORTS TODAY

body: A 27-year-old Briton was sentenced yesterday to one to to three years in prison as he continued to refuse to discuss why he was carrying a submachine gun and pistol in Brooklyn. The man, Paul John Arthur, was arrested Jan. 26 as he sat in a rented car in the Gravesend section with the weapons, a telescope and binoculars. The license plate of the
title: THE CITY; Briton Sentenced In Weapons Case

body: Baseball Brewers vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Milwaukee. This is the last home game of the season for the first-place Brewers, who go to Boston tomorrow for three games starting Tuesday and then finish up the season with four games against the Orioles in Baltimore. (Television, Channel 7, 2 P.M.) Braves vs. San Diego Padres, at Atlanta. After closing
title: SUNDAY SPORTS

title: CITY VOTE FOR TOP STATE OFFICES BY ASSEMBLY DISTRICTS; DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR

body: A visual feast will unfold in New York Harbor tomorrow as a fleet of some 200 yachts, the largest turnout in the nine-year history of the Governor's Cup race, crosses the starting line off the Battery beginning at 11 A.M. Unlike most yacht races, which take place well offshore and out of sight, this 16-mile competition takes the fleet through the
title: THE BIG YACHT RACE THAT EVERYONE CAN SEE

body: ''It took seven years of planning and pushing to turn this dump into a field,'' Carmine Santa Maria said yesterday. ''We consider it a miracle.'' The ''miracle'' is the Narrows Verrazano Youth Program Sports Complex in Brooklyn - 34 acres of park and playground that once was a landfill. At dedication ceremonies, Mr. Santa Maria, a member of the
title: LANDFILL IN BROOKLYN BECOMES SPORTS COMPLEX

body: Old Stone House Gets Flags at Last In the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, the Old Stone House of Gowanus dates back to 1699. The Dutch Colonial building was a headquarters in the 1777 Battle of Long Island, when the British landed from 400 ships in Gravesend Bay and tried to wipe out General Washington's army. Two companies from Maryland were
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Gertrude Ryder Bennett Williams, a poet and author who published poetry for many years under the name Gertrude Ryder Bennett, died July 14 at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 81 years old and had spent her life in the Wyckoff-Bennett family homestead in the Gravesend section. Mrs. Williams was the wife of the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams,
title: Gertrude R.B. Williams, 81; A Brooklyn Poet and Author

body: To the Editor: I join you in lauding the police for their promptness in arresting some of the white youths allegedly responsible for the death of a black transit worker in Gravesend (editorial June 25). One hopes the others in this mob will be arrested promptly. Along with your comment on the need for summer jobs, there are other lessons which this
title: LESSON OF A 'LYNCHING'

body: Thousands of off-duty police officers, firefighters and correction officers marched down Broadway and rallied outside City Hall yesterday to press the Koch administration to increase its wage offer in contract talks. The workers were in street clothes, but many wore T-shirts emblazoned with their department or unit. A few brought their families. As
title: UNIFORMED UNIONS RALLY TO PROTEST CITY'S WAGE OFFER

body: The murder 11 days ago of William Turks - whose only offense was that he was black - by a lynch mob of white men wielding bludgeons in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn reveals many things we find uneasy to contemplate. It tells us that in this city of abrasion and overcrowding and widening gulfs between rich and poor, employed and jobless - and
title: NEW YORK; The Walls Still Stand

body: Two more young men were taken into police custody yesterday in last week's mob attack on three transit workers in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. The arrests brought to five the number of suspects in custody. One of the workers, William Turks, was beaten to death. Police officials have said the attack on the three workers, all of whom were
title: 2 MORE SUSPECTS SEIZED BY POLICE IN MOB ASSAULT

body: A Brooklyn discotheque whose intended purchaser was shot to death early Sunday is being investigated by the State Liquor Authority for possible hidden ownership, Alan Cohen, the authority's senior investigator, disclosed yesterday. He also said the premises had a history of illegal gambling operations. The would-be buyer, Frank Fiala, a millionaire
title: DISCO IN SLAYING IS SUBJECT OF INQUIRY

body: More than 200 shouting, chanting black demonstrators marched yesterday in front of the Avenue X Bagels shop in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn to protest the beating death of a black man last Tuesday in that predominantly white area. The demonstrators were led by Roy Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, who came to the
title: 200 BLACKS JOIN MARCH TO PROTEST A FATAL BEATING

body: International Israeli leaflets fell on west Beirut, warning people to flee if they wanted to save their lives. In the meantime, Israel moved more armored units into the hills surrounding Lebanon's capital. A series of meetings to find a formula that would provide the Palestinian guerrillas with an ''honorable'' exit were held by President Elias
title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982

body: A 37-year-old man was shot to death outside a Brooklyn discotheque in an apparent gangland slaying early yesterday morning, the police said. The man, Frank Viala, whose address was unknown, was shot at 2 A.M. outside the Plaza Suite discotheque, at 2937 86th Street, in the Gravesend section, a police spokesman said. The spokesman, Officer Fred
title: Man, 37, Found Shot to Death Near a Brooklyn Discotheque

body: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man yesterday became the third suspect to be arraigned in connection with the attack on three black transit workers last Tuesday in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. One of the workers was killed. The third suspect, Anthony Miccio of 2400 East Third Street, pleaded not guilty in Brooklyn Criminal Court to charges of riot and
title: THIRD SUSPECT ARRAIGNED IN ATTACK ON THREE TRANSIT WORKERS

body: It was just after midnight on May 3 of last year. Roscoe Fountain had finished his 4 P.M.-to-midnight tour as a Housing Authority policeman at the Coney Island projects in Brooklyn. Officer Fountain was hungry. So he put on his civilian clothes and drove a few blocks, to the Gravesend section, to pick up something to eat before heading home. As he
title: A PLAYGROUND MOB, A KILLING AND A NEIGHBORHOOD ASKS WHY

body: The police arrested a third suspect yesterday in the assault on three black transit workers - one of whom was beaten to death - by a group of white youths in Brooklyn on Tuesday. The most recent suspect arrested was identified as Anthony Miccio, 19 years old, of 2400 East Third Street in Brooklyn. Officer John Clifford said Mr. Miccio had been
title: POLICE ARREST A THIRD SUSPECT IN ATTACK ON TRANSIT WORKERS

body: ''It was a bunch of kids hanging on a corner getting drunk,'' one neighbor speculates. ''These guys were probably passing by and maybe somebody shouted 'nigger,' and the words went back and forth. Then the punches came. It happens.'' But it was clearly outrageous, and it is up to the city's criminal justice agencies to make that clear after the
title: The Message of Gravesend

body: Two teen-agers were arrested yesterday in the fatal beating of a transit worker in Brooklyn on Tuesday by a taunting group of young men. The police said the attack was unprovoked and racially motivated. It occurred when the man and two fellow transit employees were on their way home from work and their car stalled. The three victims, all of whom
title: 2 YOUTHS SEIZED AS ARRESTS START IN RACIAL KILLING

body: International Israeli forces attacked Syrians just south of the Beirut-Damascus road as a cease-fire announced by Israel collapsed. The Israelis used planes, tanks and artillery in intense, daylong exchanges of fire, and fighting was reported in at least nine places along the highway. The American Embassy is closing today, and all Americans in
title: NEWS SUMMARY; THURSDAY, JUNE 24, 1982

body: Three men were attacked and one of them was beaten to death when their car stalled on a street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning. The victims, who were on their way home from work, were black, and the police said the attack was unprovoked and ''racially motivated.'' They said the victims were assaulted at 12:10 A.M. by a
title: BLACK MAN IS KILLED BY MOB IN BROOKLYN: ATTACK CALLED RACIAL

body: Officials of the New York City Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers yesterday denounced a threat by the Federal Government to require the transfer of teachers to improve the racial balance of teachers in the city's public schools. ''There is no attempt by us to claim numerical compliance with the agreement,'' said Perry Davis,
title: CITY TEACHER TRANSFERS IN MINORITY PLAN FOUGHT

body: On Monday, Jan. 11, the body of 36-year-old Isabelle Garcia, a post office supervisor, was found by her brother in the bedroom of her home at 108-12 48th Avenue in Corona, Queens. She had been shot in the head and had been dead for several days. As was her practice, Mrs. Garcia, who worked nights, had left her 8-year-old twin daughters with her
title: Crime Update; A RED HERRING IN A MURDER IN QUEENS

body: A 27-year-old British citizen, Paul John Arthur, was indicted on weapons charges in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. He was arrested last week while sitting in a rented car in Brooklyn's Gravesend section with a loaded submachine gun and a pistol beside him, according to the police. Mr. Arthur has told the police only his name, age and address in
title: THE CITY; Briton Indicted In Weapons Case

body: A suspect being held on $1 million bail for illegal possession of an Uzi submachine gun and a .45 automatic continued his silence yesterday when antiterrorist experts from the Federal Bureau of Investigation tried to question him, the authorities said. The suspect, Paul John Arthur, has refused to give the officials an explanation of why he was
title: Weapons-Case Figure C ontinues His Silence

body: An unemployed 27-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with the beating death last week of an 82-year-old woman who lived in the apartment beneath his on 18th Avenue in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn. Detective Robert J. Sasso, who made the arrest, said the suspect, Peter Augustine, would be charged with first-degree murder. The
title: SUSPECT IN KILLING OF WOMEN, 82

body: At first glance, Brooklyn's south-western shore would seem an unlikely place for residential development. It has suffered from years of decline and neglect and is cut off from Bensonhurst and Bay Ridge, two of its closest neighborhoods, by the Belt Parkway. But two local developers, who share an affinity for waterfront living, have chosen a
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A LUXURY CONDOMINIUM ALONG BROOKLYN WATERFRONT

body: The innocent bystander who was killed in what was apparently a gangland attack on two men in Brooklyn Monday night was described yesterday as a social worker who had devoted her life to helping others. The bystander, Veronica Zuraw, 53 years old, was killed in her kitchen by a shotgun blast that penetrated the second-floor door and walls of he r
title: BYSTANDER KILLED IN MOB SHOOTING WAS A SOCIAL WORKER AND EX-NUN

body: Two people - one of them a woman storing laundry in a hallway closet in her home - were killed during a gangland attempt to assassinate a convicted pornographer and Mafia member last night on a quiet, residential side street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, the police said. A third person was seriously wounded by men firing shotguns from at
title: TWO SLAIN AND ONE HURT IN A MOB-STYLE SHOOTING
